name: General Knowledge 12 Quiz | Mixed 25 Questions | 25 Questions

questions.text: Name the member of 'The Addams Family' who has the same name as a day of the week?
questions.explanation:
Wednesday.

	She is called Wednesday Thursday Addams.

questions.text: The painting 'The Mona Lisa' is also known as .... ?
Name the rabbit in the Disney film 'Bambi'?
Whose television roles include 'Steve McGarrett' in Hawaii Five-O?
What fraction of an iceberg is hidden under the surface of the sea?
Who wrote the play called 'The Mousetrap'?
The murderer of Lee Harvey Oswald was Jack ... ?
Associated with blood clots on long haul flights, what does the acronym D.V.T. stand for?
Who is the author of '101 Dalmatians'?
Which village in West Yorkshire, England, was the home of the Bronte sisters?
Name the 1924 novel by E.M. Forster?
questions.explanation:
A Passage to India.

	Edward Morgan Forster.

questions.text: The 'Statue of Liberty' in New York Harbour was a present to the US from the people of .... ?
The Sea of Galilee is located in which country?
How many sensations of taste do we have?
questions.explanation:
5.

	They include: Sweet, salt, bitter, sour and umami.  Umami has been identified as a savoury taste such as soy sauce, Parmesan cheese, etc.

questions.text: The 'Dunn's River Falls' are a major attraction on this island and the island's name comes from a Native American word meaning 'island of springs'?
In which continent would you find the vampire bat?
questions.explanation:
South America.

	They are found in the tropical regions of Central and South America.

questions.text: Which nationality of people sometimes call their country L'Hexagone (The Hexagon) because of its six-sided shape?
Who was the creator of 'Paddington Bear'?
Which children's television programme features 'The Hornblower' theme music performed by accordionist Tommy Edmondson?
In what year was the world's first training shoe launched by German sportswear manufacturer Addas (later called Adidas)?
questions.explanation:
1949.

	The three-strip shoe was designed by Adolf Dassler.

questions.text: Roger Bannister broke the four minute mile barrier with a time of 3 minutes 59.4 seconds on May 6th 1954. What was the nationality of the runner whose record of 4 minutes 1.3 seconds was beaten by Bannister?
questions.explanation:
Swedish.

	Gunder Hagg set his record in 1945.

questions.text: Each person has two natural sets of teeth during their life. The first set are milk teeth and the second are 32 adult teeth. How many milk teeth did we have?
Which place name means 'City of Lions'?
questions.explanation:
Singapore.

	Sierra Leone means 'Lion Mountains' Singapore has a misleading place name as no lions are seen there.

questions.text: Which animal can turn its stomach inside out?
questions.explanation:
Starfish.

	Starfish are very strong and can pry open the shells of clams. When attacking its victim, the starfish arches over it and clamps a couple of arms onto each side. It pulls with great strength and as the two parts of the mollusc's shell opens, the starfish turns its stomach inside out through its mouth and into the gap in the shell and begins to digest the prey's flesh.

questions.text: In the Museum of Modern Art, New York, in 1961, an artist's painting had been hanging upside-down for two months with none of the 116,000 visitors noticing. Name the artist.
questions.explanation:
Henri Matisse.

	Hope you enjoyed the quiz.
